solution_01_data_basics/04_center/02_get_median_v1

video

(ANS=51.65)

To determine the median by hand, you first sort the sample. \[\text{sort}(\mathbf{x})=50.28, 50.33, 51.15, 51.41, 51.56, 51.74, 51.85, 53.1, 53.97, 53.99\] If the sample size is odd, just find the number in the middle number (the \(\frac{n+1}{2}\)th value). If the sample size is even, determine the mean of the middle two numbers (the \(\frac{n}{2}\)th and \(\left(\frac{n}{2}+1\right)\)th values).


In a spreadsheet, you can use the MEDIAN function. You can see a solution spreadsheet here.

In R, you can use the MEDIAN function.

# First, get the csv into the working directory... then...
data = read.csv("get_median.csv")
x = data$x
median(x)
## [1] 51.65
